questions.question: What is the chemical formula of the {Cu6}-added polyoxometalate cluster-organic framework synthesized in the study?
What method was used to synthesize the {Cu6}-added polyoxometalate cluster-organic framework?
questions.answer: The {Cu6}-added polyoxometalate cluster-organic framework was synthesized using a hydrothermal method.

questions.question: What applications were explored for the synthesized {Cu6}-added polyoxometalate cluster-organic framework?
questions.answer: The synthesized {Cu6}-added polyoxometalate cluster-organic framework was explored as a solid support for enzyme immobilization, specifically for immobilizing MP-11 and Cyt c enzymes.

questions.question: How does the enzyme activity of MP-11@Cu-POMCOF and Cyt c@Cu-POMCOF in aqueous solution compare to their free enzyme counterparts?
questions.answer: In aqueous solution, MP-11@Cu-POMCOF and Cyt c@Cu-POMCOF exhibited significantly higher catalytic activity compared to their free enzyme counterparts, which experienced significant aggregation or denaturation.

questions.question: What was the impact of immobilizing enzymes on Cu-POMCOF on their thermal stability?
questions.answer: Immobilizing enzymes on Cu-POMCOF significantly enhanced their thermal stability, with MP-11@Cu-POMCOF and Cyt c@Cu-POMCOF retaining higher activity at elevated temperatures compared to the free enzymes.

questions.question: True or False: The study found that the {Cu6}-added polyoxometalate cluster-organic framework exhibits excellent stability in aqueous solutions under different pH conditions.
What was the observed effect of organic solvents on the activity of immobilized enzymes compared to free enzymes?
questions.answer: The enzyme@Cu-POMCOF complexes exhibited stability in organic buffers significantly higher than that of free enzymes, retaining a higher percentage of their activity in organic solvents.

questions.question: How was the reusability of immobilized enzymes on Cu-POMCOF tested, and what were the findings?
questions.answer: The reusability of immobilized enzymes on Cu-POMCOF was tested through multiple reaction cycles, showing excellent reusability with MP-11@Cu-POMCOF retaining 82% activity and Cyt c@Cu-POMCOF retaining 52% activity after 5 cycles.

questions.question: True or False: The study demonstrated that immobilizing enzymes on Cu-POMCOF does not protect enzymes from harsh reaction conditions.
What was the method used to determine the enzyme loading capacity on Cu-POMCOF?
questions.answer: The enzyme loading capacity on Cu-POMCOF was determined by measuring the amount of protein reduced in the supernatant using a BCA assay after mixing the enzymes with Cu-POMCOF and incubating.
